examples.0: Limited experience or knowledge. May have some familiarity but no hands-on or professional experience.
examples.1: Can create a basic (single source & type) SSIS Package/ETL to move data.
examples.2: Can effectively debug or troubleshoot an SSIS Package/ETL they haven't seen before.
examples.3: Can create advanced (multiple sources & types) SSIS Package/ETL with robust logging and error handling.

C2.competency: Understands different types of ingestion patterns (file, SQL to SQL, Queues, APIs)

examples.0: Limited experience or knowledge. May have some familiarity but no hands-on or professional experience.
examples.1: Can create an ingestion process for file drops or SQL to SQL scenarios and can explain the process effectively.
examples.2: Uses all different ingestion methods currently used (File, SQL to SQL, Queues, APIs) and can create an ingestion process for at least two.
examples.3: Creates documents, processes, templates, and examples for different ingestion use cases. Proactively seeks out new and better ingestion methods and tools and presents these to the Engineering Community.

C3.competency: Experience querying tables on SQL Server

examples.0: Limited experience or knowledge. May have some familiarity but no hands-on or professional experience.
examples.1: Writes basic T-SQL syntax with joins and aggregates. Shows the ability to use functions, SQL functions, and CTEs.
examples.2: Writes performant SQL when querying large tables.
examples.3: Writes complex SQL and understands performance trade-offs (For example: Subqueries vs. Temp tables, SELECT DISTINCT vs. GROUP BY, Indexing Temp tables, etc.).

examples.0: Limited experience or knowledge. May have some familiarity but no hands-on or professional experience.
examples.1: Follows SSMS indexing suggestions. Looks for basic operations in query execution plan using SSMS or Sentry One Plan Explorer.
examples.2: Creates columnstore and row indexes (not what SSMS suggests). Analyzes execution plan and uses stats to find real issues and other advanced features (join operators). Uses tools to measure performance against Non Functional Requirements.
examples.3: Advanced understanding of the execution plan vs the data set and the best way to structure a query to achieve the business case.

examples.0: Limited experience or knowledge. May have some familiarity but no hands-on or professional experience.
examples.1: Understands the purpose of the Bus Matrix and how to create one.
examples.2: Understands how all models fit in to a global semantic framework and the business cases they solve for.
examples.3: Is able to lead and drive discussions related to the development of the Bus Matrix as teams are globalizing data.

examples.0: Limited experience or knowledge. May have some familiarity but no hands-on or professional experience.
examples.1: Creates a Logical Model from a Bus Matrix.
examples.2: Creates a Physical Model from a Logical Model with correct data types and standard indexing.
examples.3: Applies all Modeling Global Standards to a Physical Model so it is Production Ready.

examples.0: Limited experience or knowledge. May have some familiarity but no hands-on or professional experience.
examples.1: Understands and can confidently explain basic differences between OLAP Models and OLTP Models.
examples.2: Understands and can confidently explain the pros and cons of using OLAP verses OLTP and why OLAP is beneficial for data warehousing.
examples.3: Experience implementing or supporting an OLTP Model and can confidently explain.

examples.0: Sometimes looks for code enhancements and opportunities.
examples.1: Actively improves code used in solutions regardless of the owner.
examples.2: Uses Query Store or other similar tools to proactively find areas for enhancement and updates them.
examples.3: Sets up proactive monitoring and alerting to check for quality issues (performance, error handling, logging, etc..)

examples.0: Is not familiar with Engineering Best Practices.
examples.1: Understands and follows Data Engineering Best Practices.
examples.2: Documents best practice recommendations, presents these recommendations to Senior Engineers for approval and implements them into Engineering Best Practices documentation.
examples.3: Proactively researches, recommends and promotes industry best practices in order to improve Data Engineering Best Practices.

examples.0: Includes functional testing as a normal part of the development life cycle.
examples.1: Includes functional testing and regression testing as a normal part of the development life cycle.
examples.2: Consistently creates test scripts and data validation steps for post-deployment validation. Always fully validates business use case is met post-deployment. Makes suggestions to improve best practices.
examples.3: Contributes to Best Practices and implementation of them. Shares and educates the group about using and adhering to our best practices.

B5.competency: Utilizes source control systems in their development (GIT, Redgate, TFS, other)

examples.0: Uses source control in their development to some degree.
examples.1: Performs basic functions in source control such as branch, commit, pull requests. Commits all work in source control.
examples.2: Performs more advanced functions in source control such as cloning and rebase. Can resolve merge conflicts.
examples.3: Shown expertise and is the go to person in one or more source control systems.Â Drives accountability and mentors on the source control system.

A1.competency: Knowledge of Multi-Dimensional Cubes for Analytical Processing

examples.0: Has little knowledge of Multi-Dimensional SSAS cubes.
examples.1: Understands the basic concepts of Multi-Dimensional cubes and why they are useful, knows how to browse them.
examples.2: Can design build and deploy an SSAS Cube. Can write MDX to retrieve result sets in SSMS and Stored Procedures.
examples.3: Proactively seeks to identify SSAS Cube improvements to speed, design and documents solutions. Shares them with the Engineering Community.

examples.0: Limited experience or knowledge. May have some familiarity but no hands-on or professional experience.
examples.1: Can create a Tabular model in SSDT.
examples.2: Leverages Power Query/M when building the model.
examples.3: Creates partitioning for optimal reporting (such as a hot partition.)

examples.0: Limited experience or knowledge. May have some familiarity but no hands-on or professional experience.
examples.1: Can create simple measures, calculated columns, and tables using DAX.
examples.2: Understands filter context.
examples.3: Troubleshoots performance issues and identify root causes (system gateway, DAX, processing, rendering).

A4.competency: Knowledge of front-end reporting solutions (Power BI, SSRS, Tableau, QSlice)

examples.0: Limited experience or knowledge. May have some familiarity but no hands-on or professional experience utilizing tools.
examples.1: Knows how the legacy reporting solutions are populated and how they receive data. In addition, is able to troubleshoot data in legacy reporting solutions.
examples.2: Knows how all reporting solutions are populated and how they receive data. Can troubleshoot and refresh data sets.
examples.3: Mentors others on best practices and stays up to date with new versions and functionalities of tools.

A5.competency: Experience building datasets in various reporting solutions

examples.0: Limited experience or knowledge. May have some familiarity but no hands-on or professional experience.
examples.1: Experience building datasets in one reporting systems.
examples.2: Experience building datasets in two legacy reporting systems and experience building a dataset in Power BI.
examples.3: Mentors others on building datasets in legacy reporting systems as well as Power BI.

A6.competency: Knowledge of Power BI as the reporting tool of choice

examples.0: Limited experience or knowledge. May have some familiarity but no hands-on or professional experience.
examples.1: Understands how to build a report and accompanying dataset.
examples.2: Understands the Power BI architecture (report, service, gateways, datasets) and how it integrates into the BIG framework.
examples.3: Documents how we utilize Power BI and shares it with other data engineers.

examples.0: Limited experience or knowledge. May have some familiarity but no hands-on or professional experience.
examples.1: Uses perfmon, grafana, system views, sp_whoisactive to monitor health.
examples.2: Takes action based on monitoring tools output. Can display and read SQL Server and Windows error logs.
examples.3: Sets up monitoring for servers tools. Can check and understand real time CPU, Memory, Page Life Expectancy and Wait Types.

SE1.competency: Understands data security within SQL Server

examples.0: Limited experience or knowledge. Has some understanding of how SQL Server security works.
examples.1: Understands the use of schemas, roles, users and relation to Active Directory in SQL Server.
examples.2: Is able to determine a user or group's access to objects in SQL Server.
examples.3: Implements secure data models using security at the db, schema, table, and row level.

SE2.competency: Understands data security when sharing and transmitting

examples.0: Limited experience or knowledge. Understands FOC Security policies and requirements.
examples.1: Understands AE privacy by design and legal implications.
examples.2: Can explain AE privacy policies and practices and implement it in solutions.
examples.3: Makes suggestions to improve security and auditing. Understands PII, PCI and PIFI.

examples.0: Limited experience or knowledge. Learns passively through others and attending trainings.
examples.1: Actively seeks out new technology and approaches to solutions. Applies them when possible in projects.Â
examples.2: Learns new technologies, tests them out in POC's and shares findings through demonstrations and knowledge sharing.
examples.3: Implements and applies new technologies and approaches in Production.

examples.0: Limited experience or knowledge. Knows some Cloud concepts and terms but no hands-on or professional experience.
examples.1: Knows different data stores and instance types. Can instantiate one of these and use it to load and retrieve data.
examples.2: Understands Cloud security models, functional applications within a platform and is able to apply knowledge in a system.
examples.3: Understands and helps manage costs, performance and matching of Cloud services in appropriate regions to the right business need.
